awd_abstract_narration:
The standard axioms of set theory, Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the axiom of choice (ZFC), do not decide many natural questions. For example, the Continuum Hypothesis (that there is no set whose cardinality is strictly between that of the integers and that of the real numbers) is independent of the standard axioms, as shown in 1963 by Paul Cohen through the breakthrough method of forcing.  Since then, a longstanding project in set theory has been to use forcing for relative consistency results and to study strengthening of the ZFC axioms. This constitutes the broad motivation of the project: What is possible in strengthening of ZFC, versus what constraints are imposed by ZFC itself? The educational component of the project features organizing two workshops and support for undergraduate and graduate student research.

The main candidates for ZFC strengthenings are large cardinal axioms and strong forcing axioms.  Forcing over a model with large cardinals is also the most powerful tool for showing consistency results. Combinatorial principles, especially at singular cardinals are used to understand both the nature of these extensions, and how much we can do with forcing and large cardinals. Jensen's square, Shelah's approachability property are "anti-compactness" type principles that hold in models that sufficiently resemble L. In contrast, the tree property is a reflection property that resembles large cardinal properties, but can hold at successor cardinals. The project will focus on the interplay between these principles and forcing extensions constructed from large cardinals. The PI will also investigate how they interact with the singular cardinal hypothesis and Shelah's PCF theory. The latter is mostly decided in ZFC, and provides certain "canonical invariants," against which one can test new axioms.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Modern set theory started with Cantor's discovery that there are different levels of infinity, a concept referred to as cardinality. Two infinite sets have the same cardinality if there is a bijection between them. Cantor showed that no such bijection exists between the natural numbers and the real numbers, in other words the reals are uncountable. Formally, the cardinality of the reals is greater than the cardinality of the natural numbers. 

The natural question is whether there is nothing in between: is it the case that every infinite subset of the reals is either countable (i.e. has same cardinality as the natural numbers), or is it of the same cardinality as the reals. A positive answer is known as the Continuum Hypothesis (CH) and it became the famous Hilbert's First Problem. Hilbert's first problem was partially resolved by Godel and then fully answered by Cohen, who showed that CH is independent of the  standard axioms of mathematics (ZFC). That means that CH can neither be proven, nor refuted by ZFC. The method Cohen used is called forcing.

This project was about analyzing infinite combinatorial objects, and what can be obtained about them by forcing versus what are their ZFC-constraints. One of the key notions the project focused on was the behavior of the powerset function of infinite sets. That can be thought of as a higher analogue of CH, since the real numbers can be identified as the powerset of the natural numbers. Another focus was combinatorial properties, such as the tree property, stationary reflection.

An old lemma from graph theory states that every infinite, finitely branching tree has an infinite branch. The tree property is an uncountable analogue of this statement. Intuitively, it says that a tree which is tall, but not too wide, has an unbounded branch. Here "tall" and "wide" refer to infinite cardinals. Stationary reflection has a more technical definition, but informally it says that every big set has big initial segments.

There is a deep connection between  these combinatorial properties and the powerset function. The PI's research analyzed this connection and obtained results about the interaction of the tree property, stationary reflection, the powerset function, and forcing. During the project period the PI wrote 18 papers and gave over 40 invited talks at conferences, colloquia, and seminars.

Broader Impacts: The award was used to organize workshops and support undergraduate and graduate student research. The goals of the workshops were the training of junior researchers, exposing them to current research trends in mathematics, and encouraging interaction between students, postdocs and senior mathematicians. The workshops increased the profile of mathematical logic and set theory and helped recruit talented mathematicians, often from under represented groups.

The award was also used to support the PI's graduate students by securing conference travel funding and research assistantships. During the duration of the award, four of the PI's Ph.D. students graduated and all found jobs shortly afterwards - two postdocs, one assistant professor, and one in the industry. 

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2022
Modified by: Dima Sinapova
